content:
The poem "Buying Her Dill Pickles" is a free verse poem, as it doesn't adhere to any specific rhyme or meter pattern. There are some elements of a sporadic iambic meter, but it is not consistent throughout the poem.

The symbolism in the poem is quite apparent, with the evergreen tree representing a long-lasting and fruitful relationship, while going "bonsai" suggests a stunted and unhealthy relationship. The dill pickles can represent a choice or decision that is difficult to make, similar to a pregnancy or abortion.

The speaker seems to be struggling with their identity, responsibilities, and upbringing as a Christian, particularly when it comes to the topic of abortion. The poem appears to touch on the recent Roe v. Wade case, with the lines "Techniques / No longer adhere / to the PG 13 / King James version" suggesting a change in societal views and values. The speaker seems to be torn between their beliefs and their own personal experiences, with lines like "I can’t reason / Ending a life / Vis-a-vis / having a wife" showing this internal conflict.

The final lines of the poem show the speaker seeking forgiveness from God, suggesting that they may feel guilty about past choices they have made. The use of the metaphor of the cucumber turning into a pickle can be interpreted as a metaphor for how the speaker's own innocence or purity may have been lost, but that they are seeking redemption and forgiveness.

Overall, the poem is a personal reflection on a difficult decision, but it also touches on larger societal and religious themes. The speaker appears to be grappling with their beliefs and values, but ultimately seeks guidance and forgiveness from God.
